why-overtime-isnt-actually-worth-it.text: Why Overtime Isn‚Äôt Actually Worth It

the-real-cause-of-overtime-and-how-to-av.text: The Real Cause of Overtime (And How To Avoid It)

pageProps.body:
Overtime Kills

https://www.7pace.com/blog/overtime-kills

When deadlines are looming and there‚Äôs still a lot of work to be done, the solution is simple.

Just work more, right?

After all, a person who works 90 hours a week should be at least twice as productive as a person who only works the standard 40 hours a week. That‚Äôs just simple math.

If you live in the real world, though, you already know that this is bullsh*t.

Overtime seems like a simple solution to increasing productivity, and in the short-term, it may get ‚Äúmore work‚Äù done. But eventually, overtime kills your business‚Äîits productivity, its output, its moral, its profits, and more.

To understand why overtime should be avoided at all costs, you have to understand the real damage it causes‚Äîand what causes businesses to need to work overtime to meet their goals and deadlines. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôll look into here. Read on for the details.

Why Overtime Isn‚Äôt Actually Worth It

The 40-hour workweek works for a reason.

Think about how you spend an eight-hour workday. You arrive, settle in, pour a cup of coffee, and prepare for your day. By about two hours in, you‚Äôve hit your stride and reached maximum productivity. You can probably maintain that until about hour six, when you start to get tired and wind down. After eight hours, you‚Äôre tired and it‚Äôs time to go home, but there‚Äôs still time left in the day to relax and unwind before getting a full night‚Äôs sleep so you can start the next day feeling fresh. The weekend is plenty of time to run errands, see friends and family, and fully recharge to start a new week.

Now compare that to a week of overtime. At eight hours, you‚Äôre too tired to continue to do good, productive work, but you still have to work for two or three more hours. You go home, and there‚Äôs not enough time to unwind or get a full night‚Äôs sleep.

You‚Äôre still tired when you arrive at work the next day, so you‚Äôre still unable to maximize your productivity.

Plus, as you go more days without getting enough rest, you get more and more exhausted.

Eventually, it‚Äôs possible to fall into negative productivity because of the compounding exhaustion that comes with every-day overtime.

Research shows people tend to only be able to be really productive for around three hours a day. Forcing your engineers to spend hours more than that with their butts in their chairs won‚Äôt change the fact that science says they‚Äôre not gonna get any more good work done.

Paying full wages for negative productivity obviously isn‚Äôt good for business. But it‚Äôs not the only way overtime can negatively impact your bottom line.

A Circadian study showed that required or regular overtime tends to decrease employee morale while it increases absenteeism and turnover. You‚Äôll have a harder time recruiting and retaining employees, and as we know, turnover comes with huge costs for businesses.

The Business Cost of Overtime

Let‚Äôs start with the cost of employee turnover, which is extremely well documented.

There have been studies done that suggest it costs 6-9 months‚Äô salary to replace a salaried employee. For someone making $40,000 a year, that means $20,000-$30,000 in costs to the business every time that employee needs to be replaced.

But to be honest, that estimate may even be on the low end. These are just some of these costs that come with replacing an employee:

  • The cost of hiring, including advertising, screening, interviewing, and onboarding new employees
  • Training and management time to get the new person up to speed
  • Lost productivity as the new employee learns the ropes ‚Äî¬†it can take more than a year for a new employee to reach the same levels of productivity as an existing one
  • Cultural impact and lost productivity for others ‚Äî¬†research shows other employees tend to disengage when they witness turnover.

Turnover isn‚Äôt the only way overtime may be costing your business, though. Think about trying to work when you‚Äôre exhausted. It‚Äôs not the best quality work, right? It probably takes longer to do a task you could do quickly and easily when you‚Äôre fresh and well-rested, right?

Having to pay more wages for employees who aren‚Äôt doing productive work because they‚Äôre worn out isn‚Äôt the best use of your company funds. And if those exhausted employees make mistakes and have to re-do work because they‚Äôre too tired, you‚Äôre essentially paying them to do the same work twice. Sure, humans can always make mistakes. But science shows they‚Äôre more likely to make them when they‚Äôre worn out, which means overtime is costly in terms of mistakes people will make and what you‚Äôll have to pay to fix them.

The Human Damage Overtime Causes

Overtime hurts more than just your business, though.

There‚Äôs been a ton of research done on how overtime affects workers, and the consensus is that it‚Äôs terrible for people.

A study published in the Journal of Social Science and Medicine found that 39 hours of work per week is a distinct tipping point, and that working longer than that tends to cause mental health to decline. That same study found that working more than 48 hours a week is not only detrimental to mental health but causes a noticeable decline in physical health, too.

Source: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-28141-2

A study published in the Journal of Occupational Medicine found that long work hours contribute to anxiety and depression and cause sleep quality to suffer. Another study published in Nature and Science of Sleep found a link between those long work hours‚Äîand the poor sleep quality they cause‚Äîto longterm health problems, including cardiovascular disease, Type 2 diabetes, and certain cancers.

And a study published in the Social Policy Journal of New Zealand found that working long hours harms interpersonal relationships, particularly with spouses and children.

Oof. The research is clear that overtime is massively unhealthy for your business and your people. So why do managers continue to rely on overtime at all?

The Real Cause of Overtime (And How To Avoid It)

There are a few different reasons overtime is still so prevalent, and especially in the tech industry. The biggest one is that we have a culture that glorifies working long hours. In tech, we call it ‚Äúcrunch time,‚Äù and it‚Äôs the pervasive hackathon mentality that programmers can work around the clock to meet tight deadlines.

Overtime can also happen because of management mistakes.

One of the most common management problems that leads to required overtime is not having an effective way to measure employee output. If you don‚Äôt have a way to measure what your team is actually producing, time they spend in the office is the best way you have to determine whether they‚Äôre being productive.

Avoid this by establishing a results-based way to evaluate programmer output.

This may seem like an odd directive coming from a time tracking company. But time tracking measurements can actually help your company mitigate or even eliminate the need for overtime, because you can use time-tracking data to better manage project timelines.

The time your programmers spend ‚Äúclocked in‚Äù should never be how you measure their productivity. Instead, you should be properly managing their projects to give them enough time to create the output you need ‚Äî without working crazy overtime. If project management isn‚Äôt properly keyed in, teams could be stuck trying to complete a project that should take six weeks on a four-week timeline. Combat this by hiring qualified project managers to ensure deadlines can be met within sensible work hours.
No matter the problem, working overtime is not the answer. It takes a culture shift and a solid understanding of the consequences of overtime, but eliminating it from your organization will only help your business‚Äîand your people‚Äîthrive.

> I've often described my motivation for building software to others using imagery: I like to go find a secluded beach, build a large, magnificent sand castle, and then walk away. Will anyone notice? Probably not. Will the waves eventually destroy it? Yep. Did I still get immense satisfaction? Absolutely. - [aliasxneo](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=41497113)

> We love to see the process, not just the result. The imperfections in your work can be beautiful if they show your struggle for perfection, not a lack of care. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/is-perfection-boring/)

> Simplicity, even if it sacrifices some ideal functionality has better survival characteristics than the-right-thing. - [The Rise of Worse is Better](https://www.dreamsongs.com/RiseOfWorseIsBetter.html)

> [Roberto Blake was talking about making 100 crappy videos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OnUBaQ1Sp_E) to get better over time. Putting in the reps and improving a little bit each time.
>
